title: Introduction to E-commerce Management
headline: This free online management course provides the strategies and tools required to run a successful e-commerce platform.
description: How can you become an e-commerce manager? This practical management course covers all aspects of the field to equip you with the necessary skills. Whether it is customer service or strategies used to market your products and services, we explore each aspect of the job to help you draw up a clear and compelling e-commerce management blueprint. We cover social media branding, customer engagement and payment plans and the role of data analytics.
courseDescription:
Effective management of an e-commerce platform requires taking care of many things at once. An e-commerce manager must plan for multiple aspects of acquiring new customers, servicing them and keeping them engaged while building brand loyalty. This course lays out all the elements of e-commerce management and compares it to traditional brick-and-mortar commerce and eBusiness. We then go over e-commerce business models, customer strategies and various content execution plans.

Our social media strategy section identities the crucial elements needed to engage with potential online customers. We provide straightforward explanations and helpful tips for using social media channels effectively. We explain how to adopt a customer-centric approach for an online store that complements your marketing and advertising strategy. The course then covers online transactions and compares the features, advantages and disadvantages of various available online payment systems.

Finally, we examine e-commerce analytics to highlight the importance of tracking all data related to your website’s traffic. We define an ‘e-commerce analytics environment’ and establish why management is important in e-commerce. In today’s digital world, the demand for those skilled in e-commerce management will grow as online business expands. Aspiring entrepreneurs and businesspeople can benefit from this course as they hone their ability to manage online commerce.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page
slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Distinguish between eCommerce and eBusiness.
    • Explain the types of eCommerce business models.
    • Identify and implement the five significant phases of eCommerce strategy.
    • Outline and create a customer service strategy.
    • List the product, brand and customer strategies and deal with resistance at any stage.
    • Indicate the categories in the content execution plan.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points that were covered in this module are:
    • The purchasing, selling, transferring, and trading of data, goods, and services online are called eCommerce.
    • eBusiness refers to the digital enabling of transactions and processes within a firm and gives infrastructure support to the firm.
    • eCommerce involves commercial transactions, whereas eBusiness does not directly generate revenue for the firm.
    • eCommerce and eBusiness systems function together at the business firm boundary.
    • Types of eCommerce business models are B2C, B2B and C2C.
    • The main objective of a strategy is to improve organisational performance.
    • Strategic planning has five major phases: strategy initiation, strategy formulation, strategy implementation, strategy assessment and performance improvement.
    • Good customer service means good customer retention and good word of mouth.
    • Smart businesses realise that at least part of the differentiation will come from the service quality they offer their customers.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Match a social media channel with your desired result to create a strategy.
    • Outline a personalisation strategy for marketing an eCommerce website.
    • Select the proper category for online advertising.
    • Identify and create a customer-centric approach for an online store.
    • Recognise the importance and scope of different online payment methods.
    • Indicate the use of data analytics tools to analyse website traffic.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points that were covered in this module are:
    • Well-crafted social media channels can communicate our news and ideas to many people.
    • Twitter is an excellent medium for encouraging the viral dissemination of information, and Facebook is a far more comprehensive platform than Twitter.
    • Functions of social networks– broadcasting, feedback and collaboration.
    • Blogging is an effective medium, and Blogs help to connect with an audience and attract customers.
    • Implementation of social media strategy includes determining desired results and resource needs, brainstorming with the team and navigating the red tape.
    • Teamwork and idea generation are crucial in formulating a social media content strategy.
    • Consumer characteristics include demographic factors, individual preferences and behavioural characteristics. Merchant and intermediary-related factors include merchant reputation, transaction size and trust in the merchant.
    • Product or service factors include price, quality, design, brand and other related attributes. Environmental factors include social variables and cultural or community variables.
